_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at MSI, Inc's facility.

Pursuant to the provisions of the EMERGENCY PLANNING & THE COMMUNITY RIGHT TO KNOW ACT (EPCRA), Sections: 302; 303; 304; 311; 312; Exempt from 313 and 323 as well as statutory provisions of CLEAN AIR ACT (CAA), Section 112 ? 7, the management -- presently (Mr.) Jiri VANOUREK AS Gen. Mgr. And (Mr.) Jan CEVELA as Asst. Gen Mgr. -- is fully committed to the implementation of all applicable provisions of both acts.
It appears almost redundant to point out that the prevailing interpretations of liberal courts in litigations of acts of tort serve as a meaningful incentive for the management to avoid accidents at all costs.  Therefore, for reasons that are always connected to the economic survival, we are committed to every and all measures that prevent accident of incidental releases of ammonia, our one and only extremely hazardous substance (EHS), we store, distribute and repackage for living.

To that effect we maintain a formal schedule of monthly safety meetings for all employees of MSI, Inc.  The topic of each of these meetings is carefully selected to embrace not only subjects of personal safety in handling of ammonia and adherence to our written Standard Operating Procedures and Safety Process Management, but included are individual measures and steps to prevent accidental releases of ammonia into the atmosphere and the communal vicinity surrounding our plant.

The accidental release prevention rests on four pillars of managerial baselines/sineguanons:
      A.  Regular, semi-annual reviews of all pressure vessels data base information maintained in our special excel and maximizer computer programs involving tank maintenance, repairs and testing, The data base includes dates & read-outs of hydrostatic pressure tests; ultrasound metal thickness and metal attrition read-outs if any; magnaflux inside surface integrity test; visual examination of inside and outside surfaces; d

isassemble & re-assemble of liquid and vapor valves; inspection & dating of pressure relief valve(s) -- the large pressure relief valves are shipped to respective specialists for re-testing and certified overhaul as needed and/or required --while outside metal surface is maintained with high gloss coatings in three steps surface coatings maintenance protocol consisting of sandblasting, priming with special zinc rich primers topped with long lasting polyurethane coating.
     B.  Use & deployment of the highest quality (most expensive), hose ends fitted & individually tested loading & off-loading hoses, dated for certified, guaranteed useful life by the manufacturer (Goodall), meeting & exceeding ASME specifications.
Use & deployment of the highest quality (most expensive), lowest hand-torque-only valves, safety relief valves, excess  flow valves (RegO).
Use & deployment of self-closing-when-ruptured "smart hose" by Goodall for ammonia railcars off-loading.
Hightened maintenance and frequent managerial attention to functionality of all tank mounted, primary and secondary (redundant) volumetric gauges, read-out devices, side tubes & back-up, max-liquid-level dip tubes. [The company records do not show one incident of tank overfilling with subsequent, uncontrolable safety relief valve opening in its 40 years of operating history]
     C.  Regular employee training in all applicable & relevant ammonia handling processes, procedures, ammonia handling protocol, managerial hands-on participation there-in, and company wide deployment of the "buddy" system up to one full year for new employees.
     D.  Ongoing & continued employee testing for substance abuse, along with a formal incentive program of special variable premiums paid each pay period for adherence to high quality, individual performance and responses to company  s.o.p. standards.

MSI acquired some years ago, at considerable expense, 5 sets(units) of SCBA  (Selfcontained Breathing Apparatus) that are maintained

in instant readiness to be used.  All employees have been trained in their use allowing us all to function as the first-on-the-scene emergency response team should an accidental release start to happening.  The reaction time will be considerably faster than the crew of the local fire department.
All of our employees, administrative personnel inclusive, have a ready access to medically fitted gas masks should the situation call for speedy evacuation or as personal messengers rushing to summon the help of the fire department crew.  Periodically, we stage emergency response drills.
Employees handling ammonia have a medically fitted gas masks always attached to their belt.  Most of the employees have had first aid training capable of aiding a victim of an accident.

In summary, the accidental release prevention and emerfency response policy of MSI are "living", well formulated measures & acquired skills we practice, but most certainly hope never to use.


2. Facility and the regulated substances handled.

NATURE OF THE FACILITY:  The facility is at best described as a typical AMMONIA BULK PLANT, operated in a rural setting of a small, farm community in OTHELLO, WA., Eastern Washington, often referred  to as the Island Empire of fair state.
The "trading area" of approx. 6 mile radius from its epicenter is populated with approx. 5,000 (more or less) inhabitants comprised of homes on irrigated farms and country homes of folks making their living in our fair town and/or outside communities adjacent to it.  The town proper houses about 3,000 people (more or less) and lies generally southeasterly of our plant.

LOCATION WITHIN ITS GEOGRAPHIC AREA:  The facility/site/ plant inclusive rail spur, off-loading dock, warehouse, shop with service facilities, administrative building, two private residences and the equipment parking yard is situated on 4.5 acres in the industrial zone on the west -- northwest edge of the town limits.  On its western boundary line the site adjoins size

able railroad yard that is adjoined on its western boundary with the right-of-way of the East Columbia Irrigation District where a segment of one of its main irrigation canals, the Potholes Canal, is located.  Westerly, beyond it is a vast, empty, marginal  grazing area, part of the unpopulated scab lands found west of town.  North of the site continues the industrial zone of the town including intermittently operated Onion Packing & Storage facilities, then an open area followed with a Potato Processing  Plant of J.R. Simplot Co., Hay Storage Area; Alfalfa Pellet Mill adjoined with open area of irrigated farm fields.  NE of our site are open farm fields.  Immediately east of our site is a commercial zone of the town adjoined with a thinly populated residential area, then the northern part of the town's residential area that is then better than one half a mile away.  South of our industrial site is the continuation of town's industrial and commercial zone that is a home, among other ag-related businesses, to a Readymix plant and to the Adams County fire department.
COMMERCIAL FUNCTION & MISSION: The principal activity on the site is ammonia repackaging and ammonia bulk distribution. MULTiSTAR Indusries, Inc., dba MULTiFROST, Inc., MULTiCHEM, Inc., MULTiCROP, Inc. (hereafter referred to only as MSI) buys anhydrous ammonia in railcar quantities, which the Columbia Railroad delivers to its sidings located on the northwest side of its industrial property. There it is off-loaded into its bulk trucks -- for L/TL(less than a truckload lots) deliveries -- or its stationary ammonia storage tanks. Like a fuel distributor/bulk plant operator does with fuel, we bring in anhydrous (waterless/dry) ammonia in quantities that are larger than end-users in the cold storage/food freezing industries and/or farmers want to buy, off-load it onto our bulk trucks, than in turn deliver it to the end-users that need this common refrigerant to "make cold" or apply it as a plant nutrient (fert

ilizer). Unlike the fuel bulk plant operator, we cover a considerably larger territory, are subjected to a strict DOT protocol concerning operations of our trucks on public highways and transloading safety measures. Since MSI sends its repackaged ammonia refrigerant all the way to Alaska, to where it is sold in one product dedicated, specially designed, DOT certified pressure vessels, it details these P/V's with ammonia and freights them to seaports on the west side of the state. There they are loaded on sea-going freighters (boats or barges) to be disgorged at various points of fish processors lining up the coastal waters of Alaska. 
MARKET PRESENCE, SUPPORT ACTIVITIES, MARKET OBJECTIVE:  More than 700 individual fish canners/fish processors, dairy operators, meat processors, food processors, fruit packer & processors, fruit storage operators, cold storage operators and farmers of the Columbia Basin, all the way from small family  establishments to large multi-facility national firms depend, often on very short notice, on timely performance and special technical skills of MSI, Inc. To and for that end, the support activities of MSI consist of rather strict & formal truck maintenance, pressure vessel testing, repair & maintenance, inventorying of specialized ammonia equipment parts, surface & tank coating repair & maintenance, truck detailing and road load mobilization together with administrative protocol needed to make formal, to make legal and safe shipments of the HAZMAT product, anhydrous ammonia.! Finally, we also fill with ammonia, - for a third party distributor/dealer, - small steel containers/ bottles that represent the main activity in the warehouse located on the west - SW  part of the site. As a full service dealer/distributor/ bulk plant operator, MSI supplements its new ammonia sales efforts with a variety of ammonia handling service for which there is an ongoing demand among ammonia users. Presently our ancillary activities include: Temporary or perm

anent ammonia removal from refrigeration systems, its purification & recycling, pressure vessel rentals for off-the-site ammonia storage during remodeling or repairs; vapor recovery during industrial systems repairs, ammonia salvage operations from storage vessels/receivers gutted in fire, equipment rentals for on-the-farm applications and intermediate field storage; ammonia tank testing, maintenance and labeling.

INVENTORIES: MSI, Inc inventories a variable, highly fluctuating quantities of two anhydrous ammonia grades:
The A-1; technical, super- dry,  aka  Refrigeration/metallurgical grade
The A-2; commercial, aka Ag-grade.
The former is a re-distilled, purified version of the latter. It usually contains 2-5000 pm of water, while the A-1 grade must not exceed water content of 200 ppm and 3 ppm of oil.
The storage of each grade at MSI at affected in Rail Tank Cars, varying between 0 -- 160,000# for each car. The product characteristics and behavior of the two grades is for the purposes of human exposure and environmental impact identical. Their MSDS sheets are identical and so are their environmental characteristics/properties when released.
Aside of the two rail tankers, ammonia is stored in two stationary tanks -- ASME construction -- 1 x 12,700G (max. ammonia capacity @ 85% full  56,700#; 1 x 15,000G (max. ammonia capacity @ 85% full  66,900#. The inventory in each varies from 0 to maximum capacity. There is also a 8,500G semi-trailer that is used intermittently for storage of used ammonia dedicated for clean-up and recycling. Inventory varies from 0 -- 38,000#.
All large storage tanks are isolated from each other, are independently plumbed and a release from one does not, and can not affect a release from the remaining others.
FIRE HAZARD:  None. Tanks are standing alone without any flammable material around them. The nearest building is over 180 ft away.
MAXIMUM INVENTORY:  Is never a sum of all storage capacities portrayed above, as during the operations of

the bulk plant the tanks are always in various stages of their respective capacities.  Therefore an educated estimate must be made: The inventory in all tanks rarely if ever exceeds 400,000# and stays most likely in the vicinity of 150-250000#.
MSI operates a fleet of ammonia pressure vessels in sizes varying from 500#, 900#, 1000#, 2250# and 4500# capacities that are used for ammonia transport where bulk deliveries do not fit and for ancillary ammonia handling service and assignments. These vessels are stored empty in the yard, in an open atmosphere, and are filled only as needed.

3. The worst-case release scenario(s and the alternative release scenario(s).
SPECIAL (OWN) MODELING.
GAS RELEASE. Selected as the worst-case scenario. Accidental gas release was selected as the only scenario to be considered in any modeling. The tanks are not subject to any other accidental release, with a possible exception of a malfunctioning PRV's  [Pressure Relief Valve)
Written Standard Operating Procedures / Process Management Plan include periodic maintenance & testing of the PRV's, yet even in the case of their unlikely malfunctioning,  the accidental release shall involve only a gas/vapor release. However, when ammonia vapors are released from a top of self-pressurized liquid, the liquid below is subject to rapid cooling, therefore rapid pressure drop leads to a "self-healing" of the accidental discharge. We know from experience that in a scenario where the pressure relief valve was completely broken off on a tank full of ammonia in Alaska, the same tank made a journey from Alaska to Seattle and from Seattle to Othello, WA yet the tank still contained over 65% of the depressurized, super-cooled liquid when it arrived in Othello. It did not emanate ammonia vapors beyond negligible, non-offensive amounts.

The railcars serving as temporary ammonia storage-- the bulk of stored liquid ammonia at the site-- are double shell pressure vessels equipped with top off-loading valves only,

equipped with excess flow valves on both liquid and vapor lines. The off-loading of ammonia liquid is done through Goodall's self-closing "smart-hose" designed to "heal" and close immediately subject to rapturous escape of the ammonia liquid.

Therefore, the worst-case scenario deploys only sudden and accidental release of ammonia vapors released from vaporization of 1000 gal / 5300# of liquid ammonia.
Beyond these escaped quantities, it is foreseen that the ammonia liquid will super-cool itself in the tank from which the ammonia vapors are escaping, self-heal to a minimal discharge till the liquid below is removed and the release brought under control.
Since ammonia vapors mix readily with air, they are subject to instantaneous dilution, hence the one half mile selection of the distance to the endpoint.
HISTORICALLY, 40 YEARS OF UNINTERRUPTED OPERATIONS DO NOT RECORD ANY AMMONIA RELEASE MODELED EITHER IN THE WORST-CASE OR THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO.

4. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

TECHNOLOGICAL STEPS:  MSI practices a documented maintenance and testing of its process equipment to ensure proper operations.
Mechanical Integrity. 1) Strict adherence to the maintenance & testing protocol of all ammonia pressure vessels and its instruments. 2) Deployment of the highest (most expensive) quality brand(s) of valves, pressure relief valve, excess flow valves, hoses, pipes, fittings etc connected with ammonia conveyance. 2) Strict adherence to engineering standards of the industry as well as installations of redundant excess flow valves on all tanks and throughout the system. 4) Uncompromising dedication to rust prevention, inhibition, control.


PROCEDURAL / MANAGERIAL STEPS: Our facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40CFR part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program t

hat is in place at our stationary site.
Process Safety Information.  MSI maintains safety information that describes the hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with its operation(s).
Process Hazard Analysis.  MSI conducts reviews to ensure that hazards associated with our operations are identified and controlled effectively. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA update was performed DEC 15, 2003.
Operating Procedures & Training. For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, MSI deploys the "buddy" system to implement operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shut-downs, emergency . Operations. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. A new employee is assigned to a "buddy" and stays with him for the entire training period  which may last up to one year. Furthermore, managers / supervisors are involved with hands-on participation in the process and their daily, hour-by-hour supervision.
Management of  Change. The most recent review / revision of the maintenance protocol was performed in December 2003. All employees, in once a month safety meetings, are appraised of the changes and trainings are conducted to deal with the changes / modifications.
Pre-start-up reviews. The start-up reviews are very rare. Our processes of dealing and handling ammonia hardly change. Consequently, the routine is well defined and followed.
Compliance Audits. MSI audits are informal & ongoing. With the management living on the premises and participating daily in the supervision, often engaged physically in the tasks at hand, the implementation and compliance with the RMP provisions is constant and continuous.
Incident Investigation. MSI would investigate formally & investigate promptly any incident that wou

ld result in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of regulated EHS, anhydrous ammonia. Formal reports would be written up and needed preventive corrections / improvements will be promptly followed. For 40 years of our operations we have been spared this formality. No incidents, nor any accidents have ever occurred and we are doing everything we can to keep the stellar record unblemished.
Employee Participation. MSI has always considered the safety process management, as well as the accident prevention efforts & goals to be a team effort. Therefore, all employees are strongly encouraged to express their views on issues of accident prevention and to make suggestions for its improvement. At the same time our employees have at all times access to information(s) that are a part of our implementation of the RMP including information resulting from the process hazard analysis in particular.
Outside Contractors: MSI informs outside contractors of known potential hazards related to contractors' work in our work process  and/or on the facility. They are also informed of the emergency response should an accidental release of ammonia occur.


5. The five year accident history. 40 years of accident / incident / unwanted release free history.


6. The emergency response program.

MSI operating since 1986 -- (prior to that date operated as SOIL & CROP SERVICE, Inc since 1963) -- has not had any recordable ammonia release in all these years. In late July, summer of 2001, a group of thieves, assumed producers of controlled substances, attempted an ammonia theft from our 8,500G storage tank.  They did not succeed, but in the process of their theft they left a liquid valve slightly cracked. The escaping ammonia created an alarm that we brought internally immediately under control with the aid of our SCBA apparatus. Valve closed, end of alarm, end of ammonia release. The estimated amount of escaped ammonia was under 100#. While the local police & the county fire depart

ment got involved, the ammonia release was handled by MSI personnel living on the commercial premises. While, ahead of the attempted theft the valve handle on the tank was capped and locked, following the release, the valve was redundantly capped with a steel cap equipped with heavier lock. No left attempts have been registered since.
MSI has an emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including first aid & medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.
To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.
Adams County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.


7. Planned changes to improve safety.  Having covered all aspects of the emergency response plan already; working only with one hazard namely anhydrous ammonia, MSI has no additional plans at this time. The management firmly believes that the operations & processes are managed clean, uncluttered, that the housekeeping is above par and that the measures for accident / incident prevention are at a very high level of alertness, preparedness and ready responsiveness.


8. Certification Statement for Program 2 & 3 Processes.

To the best of the undersigned knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable injury and scrutiny, the information submitted is true, accurate & complete.
